title: What Was Cooler Master THINKING?  H100 ITX Case Review
description: The Cooler Master H100 ITX case looks amazing at first glance but even for a small form factor case, there are a ton of sacrifices.  Even with a massive fan, airflow might not be all that great and you can barely fit a GPU.  But while this might not be the best ITX case of 2019, there might still be some interesting qualities..so let's check it out.    Buy items in this video from Amazon at the links below:  Cooler Master H100:   Zotac RTX 2060 Super ITX:   Blade Stealth Base:  Blade Stealth Graphics:  Core X eGPU:   Subscribe    Review unit provided free of charge by Cooler Master. This video is sponsored by Razer. As per Hardware Canucks guidelines, no review direction was received from manufacturer.   As an Amazon Associate we earn from qualifying purchases.   Gear list (Available on Amazon):  Main Camera -  Main Lens -  Main Camera Mic -  Second Camera -  $700 Camera (Panasonic G7) -  Sigma 18-35mm F1.8 -  Cinevate DUZI Slider -  AKG C314 -  AKG C 568 B -  Zoom H5 -  ------------------------------------------------------------ Our full site:  Join Our Forums:   Follow us for more updates! Twitter  FaceBook  Instagram  ------------------------------------------------------- #coolermasterh100 #itxcase #hardwarecanucks
transcript: well hello good people I'm Dimitri and welcome to my review of the Cooler Master h100 ITX enclosure we first saw this and behind closed doors at CES they pulled us a sign they were like what do you think my first impression was I appreciate their commitment to the design language of the Age series obviously it's like a miniature version of the H500 mesh because of the mesh front panel because of the whole exterior design language but the interior cube for factor is a bit confusing because it has pretty strong limitations in terms of cooling and GPU compatibility but interestingly when they did their market research for this price point for this target audience they found that a lot of people were using ap use aimed EAP use therefore no graphics card required and I guess cooling is not really that big of an issue as long as they have a stock cooler and I understand their direction to potentially target this case towards that demographic but it's almost like Cooler master is shooting themselves in the foot by limiting to that demographic and not doing anything innovative on the interior to potentially cater to somebody who might want a beefier GPU or more importantly a nice CPU cooler as well with long battery life an Nvidia MX 150 GPU and Intel Core i7 processor in a compact design the Razer Blade stealth 13 is a great companion for users on the go if you want more gaming her hook it up to the core X EGP with support for both AMD and NVIDIA GPUs the Razer Blade stealth plus the core X the ultimate power couple and so for $69 it kind of caters to that exact of a graphic who are not using a beefy GPU or no GPU at all and just going stock cooler ITX motherboard ATX power supply and that's it so I feel like there are four main selling points for this enclosure number one is the top handle making this a pretty portable solution for ITX Alto it's a fairly large case for this foam factor compared to something like the end case that can actually do water cooling versus this thing mmm not so much number two we have that massive 200 millimeter fan that front that is RGB it is the 12 volt RGB connector you can connect it to your motherboard for example but it also has its own controller so you don't necessarily need to connect it to the motherboard you can also reroute the reset switch into the controller unfortunately the pins on my controller were totally bent out of the way so quality control color master not good the third point is ATX PSU support which is not common for ITX cases it's great to have it here because you can potentially reuse your other components to build a system but it's also a little bit of a compromise in terms of cooling and for number four I would say it's a pretty good looking enclosure that could go into your living room or your desktop and given the side panels that completely closed off in solid you don't really see the mess that it could be inside hiding but that's out of sight out of mind the i/o is pretty basic with dual USB 3 is power reset button and your audio jacks it is important to note that the power supply bracket at the back extends beyond the frame to accommodate extra clearance on the inside so you can mount a 210 millimeter PSU without the radiator at the front or up to 160 millimeter PSU if you install a radiator in the front yeah and moving inside beyond the drive bracket that can house two SSDs we have a very simple interior you can alter them and remove the other side panel to access whatever is behind the motherboard so everything is done on the interior you'll have to do some creative work with cable management otherwise yeah cables will be all over the place unfortunately none of the motherboard standoffs are captive so you have to hole your motherboard in place and then screw everything in and given the power supply is basically installed above the CPU areum CPU tower clearance is limited to 83 millimeters so basically all stock coolers are fine or going to low profile design is necessary and I would not recommend going with the raid heater in here at the front you can do a 120 or 140 or 200 million radiator but going with a radiator at the front limits your GPU clearance which is already pretty short at maximum 210 millimeters so like an RTX 2060 founders Edition which is a super short card will not fit inside this enclosure you have to opt out for actual ITX small form-factor graphics card to fit inside the h 100 I went to the zotac rtx 2060's super which is the perfect fit for this enclosure but as you look at the bottom there is no ventilation area we only have holes for an SSD or a three and a half inch drive and again that is a massive compromise given there is no ventilation for the GPU outside of whatever's coming in from that front panel this is a pretty interesting and disappointing airflow design because there's nothing in the rear for exhaust simply there's no room so they rely on passive air being pushed out from the front fan but the top has a ventilation mesh and you could easily mount a 120mm fan up there even with a handle installed onto the frame and they didn't so it'd be great to have additional ventilation but it's not present and so the temperatures really do suffer in the default configuration 86 degrees Celsius on the GPU at 80% fan that is pretty hot while opening a side panel does drop the GPU temps by 3 degrees and only 2 degrees for the CPU honestly I was expecting a little bit more innovation from cooler master with regards to this sort of cube format potentially moving the power supply literally somewhere else beside the motherboard because there's so much space wasted that is not occupied by the cables and normally with a cube design like this you'd expect the power supply to be mounted somewhere at the front to allow for the CPU tower clearance area because if the power supply wasn't here you'd have so much space for beefy CPU tower to completely and efficiently cool the CPU while the GPU compatibility would still be pretty short given the cube form factor and the price point is also an issue 6 9 bucks is too much I think this is a $49 case even though we have a 200 mm letter RGB fan the front but the limitations are too severe to consider building something you know even mid-range and here because you have to consider GPU size and CPU cooler and not too hot of a CPU to run in this thing and all that kind of combines together to give you limitations that would outweigh the budget price point but you know what guys I'm excited for the new lian li t150 just showed up and that is where innovation happens stay tuned for that video make sure to subscribe check out this other relevant content above you and next week
